Welcome to the 449 Blair Robot Project Deep Space Scouting App!

For each match, you will be assigned a team to scout. Watch this robot closely throughout the match, and record what they do.
On each page, fill out the fields, and then move on with the navigation buttons at the bottom. You can go pack to a previous page to edit that data.

When you are done, hit the submit button.
If you realise you entered something wrong after submitting, you can edit it. Hit the edit icon at the top of the screen, select the match, and hit edit. Any data you entered for the next match will be preserved for when you finish editing.

On many questions you will see a ? icon. Click this to get more information about that field
If you need more help with something, don't hesitate to ask a scouting leader.
Please talk to a scouting leader for help.
If the team\'s robot is not on the field for this match, select the box.
Record the match number.\nIf this is a rematch, just put the match number that it is a rematch for.

Each time the robot you are watching places a game piece, record it here.
Click a circle once to place a hatch, twice for a cargo, and three times if they place both. A fourth click will clear it.

It does not matter which rocket is which, or which side of the cargo ship is which.

Please only record pieces placed by YOUR robot, and INCLUDE those placed in the Sandstorm period.

If the robot places multiple cargo in one location, don't record it.
Each time your robot drops a game piece that they had previously been holding, for any reason (including if they are trying to place it and miss), please record it here by clicking the + button.

What HAB level did the robot start on?
Level 1: the low base with a small ramp
Level 2: the two short platforms about 6 inches above level 1.
If the robot is a no show, you can leave this blank (or just put 1).
What game element did the robot start the match with?

If the robot moved and made it off of the HAB platform onto the carpet DURING SANDSTORM, check this box.\n(You may be familiar with \'Moved Forward\' or \'Crossed Line\' from past games - this is the same idea)
If the robot successfully placed their preloaded game piece DURING SANDSTORM check this box.
If the robot picked up and placed another game piece DURING SANDSTORM select the game piece that they placed. Otherwise, select "No" (or leave the item blank).

What HAB level did they ATTEMPT to climb to?

Level 1: bottom platform
Level 2: two mid-level platforms (~6in)
Level 3: highest platform (between the two level 2 platforms)

Do your best to judge intent, if they doing something that looked like it was supposed to get them up, that's an attempt. If you aren't sure, don't hesitate to ask a scouting lead.

Did the robot climb successfully? A successful climb has the robot reach and stay at the level they attempted. If no climb was attempted, simply put N/A (or leave it blank). A level 1 climb (the base platform) does count as a climb.

At the end of the match, what level was the robot at? (1 is the bottom platform, 2 is either of the two middle platforms, 3 is the highest platform)
To be a legal climb, the robot must:
 - be fully supported only by things at or above the level they have climbed to
 - have bumpers above that level.
 - have left the HAB at some point in the match

If, for example, a robot tries a level 3 climb, but they are supported by the side of the platform, above the height of level 2, this would count as a level 2 climb.

If the robot completed a level 2 or 3 climb, approximately how long did they spend, from the time they drove onto level 1 to the time they were stable and supported only by the level they are climbing to, with bumpers above that level.\nYou can use the timer to help count, or you can manually adjust the value by dragging it up or down.

Alive: the robot was enabled, moving, and mostly functional for most of the match.

Broken: robot was moving, but something is wrong. There are parts of their robot that are clearly broken.

Half dead: Dead for a significant portion of the match (think 35â€“70%).

Dead: Robot is just sitting on the field unable to move.

If the robot attempted defense, how good was it?

 - Good defense would effectively prevent a robot from scoring many game pieces, or greatly decrease their cycle time (and doesn't cause lots of fouls).
 - 'Meh' defense has a small impact on the game. It hinders the opponent a little bit, but they are able to work around the defender.
 - Bad defense is completely useless, and doesn't have any impact on the opponents, or it results in many fouls, or is interfering with alliance partners.

This is a subjective field, just put whatever you feel is best. Don't worry about choosing the 'correct' option, we have qualitative scouting for more accurate/detailed defense data.
